awd_titl_txt: Control of Molecular Quantum State Character by Coherence Effects
awd_abstract_narration:
Marjatta Lyyra's research group at Temple University is supported by the Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics Program to carry out a series of fundamental studies of the interaction of light with small molecules in the frequency domain. Her group has developed applications of quantum optics for molecular systems including electromagnetically induced transparency and the Autler-Townes (AT) effect.  These studies have facilitated a shift of quantum optics studies to molecular systems with practical applications as the goal. 

The complex molecular energy level structure, molecular interactions, and relaxation pathways provide a rich testing ground of coherence effects for controlling molecular dynamics and quantum state character. Through combined experimental and theoretical studies her research group has demonstrated control of molecular angular momentum alignment, for example. Another important application of the Autler-Townes effect is its use as a precision probe of the internuclear distance-dependent transition dipole moment functions, which are at the heart of the interaction of light with molecules. These measurements rely on the measurement of the Autler-Townes splitting from the lineshape of the control laser transition combined with an accurate measurement of the electric field amplitude of this laser. Another application of the AT effect involves external optical control over the mixing between a pair of closely-spaced molecular singlet and triplet eigenstates that are weakly perturbed by the spin-orbit interaction. The AT effect causes the nominal singlet level to split into a pair of field modified levels, one of which tunes closer to the triplet, resulting in increased singlet-triplet mixing, and the other farther from the triplet, resulting in decreased singlet-triplet mixing. Thus this optical control mechanism can be used to "tune" the spin-orbit mixing coefficients and as a result control quantum state singlet and triplet character.

In addition to developing new applications of quantum interference and coherence effects, this research bridges traditionally separate research communities: molecular spectroscopy and dynamics on one hand, and quantum optics and control on the other hand. Due to the fundamental nature of this research the results are broadly applicable. Examples include finding optimal excitation pathways for ultracold molecule formation and role of valence electron spin polarization in photochemistry.

In this project, young scientists, many of whom are women, participate in forefront scientific research at the undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral levels and as a result develop critical experience and confidence for their future participation in the scientific and technical workforce.

por.por_cntn:
The central theme of this project has to do with the interaction of light with molecules, which have a much more complex internal energy level structure than atoms consisting of rotational and vibrational energy levels in many electronic states. In our experiments coherent laser light is used to study and develop control mechanisms for molecular systems as well as to probe molecular energy level structure with high resolution.

Molecules are formed when atoms interact with each other and chemical bonds are established. Typically it takes at least two electrons to create a chemical bond between two atoms. The internal magnetic moments (spins) of these electrons can be parallel (triplet states) or antiparallel (singlet states). Atoms and molecules in gas phase are in constant translational motion which inevitably leads to collisions between them. For molecules the collisions are often inelastic resulting in the population transfer from one internal state to another. The study of such collisions under well defined and controlled conditions is of importance for processes such as chemical reactivity.  We have demonstrated experimentally optical control of the transfer of molecules between singlet and triplet state manifolds using the Lithium dimer as a test system in collisions with Argon atoms. States that are ordinarily “pure” singlet or triplet states can become “mixed” in the presence of interactions between them and thus exhibit singlet and triplet character at the same time. An example of such an interaction is the coupling between the spin and the orbital motion (spin-orbit coupling) of the electrons around the nucleus. The control is achieved by manipulating the spin character in a pair of singlet-triplet mixed levels using strong laser radiation. As a result, we have shown that the rate coefficient of a collisional process between molecules in excited states and atoms can be effectively manipulated with a laser, leading to internal spin multiplicity change in the molecules.

Chemical bonds may arise from the electrostatic force of attraction between atoms with opposite charges (ionic bonding) or through sharing of electrons (covalent bonding).  Often the character of a chemical bond is a mixture of covalent and ionic bonding. Using the Sodium dimer molecule as a test system we have studied theoretically and experimentally how the changing character of the bond as a function of the internuclear distance affects the  transition dipole moment and lifetimes of the excited electronic states.The transition dipole moment is an important parameter, which characterizes the strength of the absorption and emission of light. We have observed that the interactions between the covalent and ionic potential energy curves lead to a strong internuclear distance dependence of the electronic transition moments in the regions of the avoided crossings of these potentials. This effect is also the cause for the formation of additional wells and shoulders in the potential energy functions of these states and is reflected in their lifetimes.  

In the area of the spectroscopy of molecular electronic states we have collaborated with several other research groups on the high resolution spectroscopic study of the Rubidium dimer. Detailed and accurate knowledge of the potential energy functions of this molecule is of critical importance for ultracold molecular gases, an area of research that involves cold atom/molecule collisions, creation and exploration of quantum condensates, coherent control, and precision measurements. We have investigated spectroscopically the triplet ground state as well as a number of excited electronic states of Rb2, and provided experimentally observed accurate potential energy curves for these states.

To broaden the exposure of our students to science at the international level we have collaborated with number of international research groups. We have emphasized participation of underrepresented groups in the research effort. A number of female students were actively involved in our research during this grant period. We have also provided access to our research equipment for  upper level Physics undergraduate students and Chemistry graduate students at Temple University through the labs associated with the Physics 4302 course (Optics), taught by the Principal Investigator.
